July 18, 1933.

Memorandum:

Mr. Williams,

The Department authorized last month some repairs and improvements to the school lot at Odanak, on the Abenakis Reserve, Que., which work is being performed by day labour under the supervision of a white foreman, and is outlined in the list turned out hereunder.

As some of these repairs are very important, I would suggest that I be authorized to make an inspection of the work the beginning of next week, which inspection will require my absence from the office for three or four days.

Approved,

[Signature]

DEPARTMENTAL ENGINEER.
July 31, 1925.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 4th instant, requesting to be furnished with an advance of $100.00, which has been sent you, to be used for the paying of wages in connection with the repairs which are being carried out to the school property at Omand, I should like to be advised as to whether it will be necessary to make a further advance for the paying of wages before the work authorized is completed.

I would also request that all accounts due to date should be sent in for payment, after they have been duly verified by the foreman, accompanied by the required vouchers certified to by you, on which the R. R. number should be indicated, namely R. R. 677.

I would advise you that an officer of this Department will make an inspection of the work above mentioned sometime next week, then it will be necessary for you to advise him of the total expenditure to date.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

July 31, 1935.

Dear Sir,

I am advised by the Engineer of the Department that the total amount expended to date in connection with repairs authorized to the school property at Odanak are practically completed, and that the total expenditure up to the time of his visit on the 26th, amounted to approximately $780.00.

I understand that the remaining work consists in additional grading in the school yard, the filling of some depressions in the embankment, and the repairing and painting of the iron shing roof of the school. I would ask you, therefore, to arrange with the foreman to have this work completed as speedily as possible. It will also be necessary that you send in by return mail all accounts due to date, verified and certified by the foreman and yourself. These accounts should be accompanied by the required vouchers on which the R.R. number should be clearly indicated (namely 6071), as mentioned in my letter of the 1st instant.

With regard to the construction of a galley which has been authorized on the Retro Road road in front of the street leading to the school, I beg to say that all accounts in connection with this work should be kept separately.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, September 30, 1933.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the voucher which you submitted in your own favour for $793.86, covering the cost of materials purchased for repairs at the St. Frances R.C. Indian Day School.

It is not possible to issue a cheque in your favour as the accounts which you forwarded have not been paid by you. You should submit a separate account, in triplicate, in favour of each of the firms from whom supplies were purchased. The accounts which you submitted are returned in order that you can prepare the vouchers required by the Department.

I am also in receipt of your voucher for $673.21, covering the cost of labour and showing a balance on hand of $105.36. This amount should be returned to the Department.

When returning the accounts for material, you should forward a detailed statement showing what work has been done. The expenditure incurred is somewhat larger than the Department expected and, therefore, we require a complete report from you in order that our files may show in what manner the money was expended.

I wish, also, to refer you to the last paragraph of official letter of July 31st, last. Please advise if all accounts in connection with the construction of a gulley on the Notre Dame road in front of the street leading to the school have been kept separately.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

B. J. Maurault, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pierreville, Que.
Ottawa, October 3, 1933.

Sir:

Since writing you on the 30th ultimo, the Department has had an opportunity of checking your account of September 17th for $673.21, covering the expenditure made for labour at the St. Frances Indian Day School during the past summer. The pay sheets which you made out are so badly prepared that the Auditor General will not accept them.

With special reference to the pay list for the period July 31st to August 5th, I would point out that this pay list does not appear to be signed by the persons who received the money. On the pay list for the period July 12th to 20th, it is shown that Louis Robert worked 59 hours at the rate of 27 cents per hour, less 10 percent. The amount due him was $14.38 and not $15.37. I am, therefore, returning all the pay lists which you forwarded, and would request you to prepare these again on the proper forms, a supply of which is enclosed. You should also arrange to have them signed by the individuals who received the money.

Please give this matter your immediate attention, as these pay lists, properly completed, should have been forwarded to the Department some weeks ago.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

H. Maurault, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pierreville, P.Q.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your post card of the 20th instant, and in passing I may remark that the Department would prefer that all official communications should be sent under cover and not on post cards. As letters addressed to the Department are carried free, you are not put to any expense in postage.

In reply to your remarks about the irregular attendance of the children of Albert George, Peter Anoosaga and John George, I beg to say that I shall write to the Indian Agent at Saugeen, Mr. Smith, in English, and ask him to take the first opportunity of seeing the Indians named, and use his influence with them to obtain a better attendance of their children.

Your obedient servant,

A. N. McNEILL,
Assistant Secretary.

Ottawa, 30th September, 1895.

Sir:

The Department has just been informed by Miss Annie Rogers, Teacher of the Stony Point Indian School, that the children are very irregular in their attendance, especially those of Albert George, Peter Sandosage and John George, and that she thinks that the irregularity is due to carelessness on the part of the parents.

I have to request that on the first convenient occasion you will try to see the Indians named and persuade them to send their children to school more regularly.

Your obedient servant,

A.K. McNeill
Assistant Secretary.

To Dep. Superintendent General of Indian Affairs

Sir:

I beg leave to submit the following report on the matter of opening the school at the Story Point Reserve.

There are as nearly as I can tell from personal visits and inquiry seven children of school age on the Reserve who belong to the band and in addition three other Indian children who do not belong to the band.

These all reside convenient to one another and convenient to the school house.

From the nearest corner of the Story Point reserve it is at least 3½ miles to the Kettle Point school.

The children are all quite young.

The nearest white school is at Ravenswood about two miles from the nearest children.

There is on the Reserve in a quite central location a fairly good school house formerly used but abandoned some years ago on account of there being only one child attending. There are good desks and a teacher's table which perhaps wants a book or some trifling chairs and there is also a stove which has been taken out for safe keeping but can be got back easily.

The estimated cost would be $300 per annum for a teacher.

Wood, say $15-$25 per annum.

Cleaning & $10-$15 per annum.

Some of the children have gone to school anywhere and will have to make a start at the beginning.

From my own knowledge of the matter I recommend the opening of the school and have told the Indians that when the Department was made aware that there was 10 Indian children at Story Point it would likely insist on the school being opened.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

William [Last Name]

Ottawa, June 5, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. Agent Nisbet, of Sarnia, forwards a resolution from the band asking for the reopening of the Stony Point school. This school was closed seven years ago on account of poor attendance.

The Agent has made a report on this application, which shows that there are at least ten children of school age who are receiving no education, on account of the distance from any other school.

The Band can well afford to maintain a school, and I would recommend that the resolution be approved and that it be given another trial after the summer holidays.

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that in compliance with instructions from the Department and after consulting with Inspector Mather - Public School Inspector for New London, I have received an application from Mrs. William Clark of the Stone Point Reserve for the position of teacher in the Stone Point School to be opened at the close of the summer holidays, which will be in the month of August. This is the only application received since it was resolved to open the Stone Point school and I recommend her appointment.

She holds an High School entrance certificate and after getting it attended the Forest High School for a year. She is about 25 years of age, is a widow, and a member of the band - i.e., the Chipewa of Carmaux Lake Band and Kettle Point - and appears to be clever and intelligent. The scholars will all be in the first book, none of them ever having attended school. I have made arrangements to have the schoolhouse repaired, the lock of the door being broken and the windows broken.

I remain, Sir,

Sec.-Department of Indian Affairs,
Attawa.

Sir:

I beg leave to make application for an increase of $40 per annum in my salary as teacher at Slaley Point School. I have already served 3 years and 6 months and I feel that I am entitled to have my salary raised by that amount. School teachers' wages now are much higher than they were when I engaged to teach that school first. My experience gained during the 3½ years I have taught should make my services more valuable than they were at first. I feel that I am better qualified to do good work than at any time previously to this.

Thanking you in advance,

I remain Yours Truly,

Mrs. Robt. Wilkinson.
Sir,

I hereby enclose an application from Mr. Robert McHannon of Stone Point Reserve for a raise of salary as teacher of the Stone Point School. There is no doubt as to Mrs. McHannon's energy and ability as teacher. She commenced at Stone Point school without any previous experience but although she was an Indian girl, born on Stone Point Reserve she had obtained a good education first at the Indian schools and afterward at Forest High School. When she first took charge of the Stone Point school she was the wife of William Bland, a Stone Point Indian. She is now married to Robert McHannon, a young Scotchman who lives in the neighborhood and is living in her own house quite close to the school. There is now no complaint made against her although owing to jealousy on the part of her own relatives and neighbors which seemed to arise from the fact that she was better educated and better dressed and after she got a regular salary seemed to be doing better than the other young Indian women—there were a good many complaints the first two years principally charging her with drinking intoxicating liquor. I investigated all of these but there was no evidence to warrant even suspicion. Most of the stories when traced up had no foundation as regarded her. One woman had heard her crying on the road but that was explained easily on other grounds. Speaking candidly she has done very well and has been energetic and intent on succeeding and I think her fairly earned a reasonable increase. Mr. Bland the husband thinks she has done well all things considered and favors a modest increase in her salary.

(Signed) Assistant Agent William Knight

MEMORANDUM -

Mr. Scott -

SARNIA.

On July 1st I left for Sarnia, arriving there on the second instant; spent the afternoon of that day on the Sarnia Reserve, where I found things generally in very good condition. The prospects for good crops are excellent. My mission here was to look into the question of the amalgamation of the Kettle Point and Stony Point Schools. On Saturday the Agent and I visited these two reserves. I do not consider the suggestion that was made to amalgamate these two schools practicable, for two reasons; first, that they are far apart, the distance being over five miles, and, secondly, there is not proper accommodation now at the Kettle Point School for the children enrolled. Even if a new school were being built at Kettle Point, and
if it were erected on the same location as the present one, the distance would almost preclude driving the children from Stony Point. There are about ten children of school age at Stony Point, but the attendance has not been what it should. It may be that this is due partly to the fact that Miss Weaver does not appear to have the full confidence of the parents, which may be partly owing to antagonism on the part of Mrs. McKinnon, a former Indian teacher, who would like to be re-instated in this school, and who, you will remember, was dismissed sometime ago for bad conduct. The Public School Inspector, Mr. Conn, whom I interviewed, speaks very well of Miss Weaver.

I would recommend that the school be continued temporarily under Miss Weaver and that the Agent be instructed to inform the parents that they must send their children regularly to school, or, otherwise, resort will have to be had to the regulations, which provide for committal to industrial schools under such circumstances.

I am of opinion that such a notice will have a salutary effect.

A.F. [Signature]

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Ottawa, October 26, 1920.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Miss Agnes Weaver, teacher of the Stony Point Indian Day School, has applied for an increase in her salary. She is at present receiving $550.00 per annum, with bonus additional at the rate of $150.00, a total amount of $700.00.

Miss Weaver has been teaching ten years at this school. She has no professional qualifications. The Public School Inspector states that she is making good success in her work. The general management of the school is good and the children are making fairly good progress. Agriculture (gardening) is being taught with good results; sewing and knitting were receiving proper attention.

The attendance at this school is not large. The teacher states that all of school age are enrolled and are in attendance. The enrolment is 11 pupils; the average attendance for last year was 5. The teachers in the other two schools in the vicinity, namely, Kettle Point and St. Clair, receive salaries of $650.00 and $600.00. The enrolment at both these schools, however, is much larger, being 31 at Kettle Point and 36 at St. Clair. The salaries at all these schools are paid from band funds.

I would recommend that Miss Weaver, in view of her long service and the report of the Inspector as to the success in her work, receive an increase of $50.00, which would make her salary at the rate of $600.00 per annum, and that such increase date from the 1st instant.

Madam:

Replying to your letter of the 11th instant, I beg to inform you that a copy of the Indian Act is being sent you, under separate cover. Sections 9 to 11, inclusive, comprise the school regulations.

Corporal punishment should only be inflicted in the case of insubordination or flagrant breach of discipline. It is considered that only in very rare instances should it be necessary for a teacher to resort to whipping a pupil. We have no regulations regarding this matter, and rely on the discretion of the teacher.

Regarding the water supply, I beg to say that we took this matter up with Mr. Agent Paul. We are today in receipt of a communication from him, in which he states the well is still in good repair but lacks water. He informs us that he has made arrangements to have a supply of water placed in the well, and when this is done the difficulty will be overcome. It is hoped that the agent has attended to this matter and that there will now be water available.

Your obedient servant,

I am taking this opportunity to bring to your attention the necessity for a new school building at Kettle Point.

The present school house is altogether too small for the number enrolled. The desks are crowded too closely together and it is necessary in some instances to seat three pupils at one double desk. The building itself is old and rather than spend any money on repairs it would be advisable to erect a new school with teacher's residence included.

The parents are taking more interest in sending their children to school and are anxious to have better accommodation.

In this connection it would be as well to give some consideration to a central school for the two reserves. From a casual survey of the situation, I think that this is a matter which Schools Branch should give careful consideration. There are never more than ten or eleven pupils at Stony Point School. This seems to be too few to warrant the expense of upkeep and teacher's salary. The Kettle Point School would be better situated if built up on the hill near the church. This would bring it much closer to Stony Point reserve and an arrangement could probably be made for transportation of pupils daily to the school and return. I mention this only as a suggestion for consideration and not as a proposition, which has been given careful thought. I do, however, strongly recommend a new school for Kettle Point reserve and that the location be changed to a more central point.

Dear Sir,

I am taking this opportunity in writing this letter to you this evening. I am at a loss just at present not knowing what to do next regarding the children on the reserve. I hear so many rumours going around.

Robert George (our councilor for Stoney Point Reserve) lives about half a mile from the school and he will not send his children to school. It is a shame the way he is bringing these boys up. He lets every one of them chew tobacco and smoke cigarettes—Even the smallest, which is five years old. I tried to stop him but it is useless. Robert gives them the stuff.

I feel sorry for the boys.

John Johnson gave me a visit about three weeks ago and I did everything to help him. And while the supper was going on—I had a little fuss with Rachel Henry. The girl was so interested in a year or so ago. I did nothing to her, I only told her to quit running around with one of our boys—as she is not fit for any young man to go with—according to Dr. McDonald (our doctor). I guess she got offended over me chastising her and I heard her talking about me later on in the evening, calling me all kinds of names.
I asked her what she meant by doing it, and she got very angry at me. She shrieked in my face, but I gave it back to her.

Now I get all the blame, that is why Robert George will not send his boys. And I am told that Stanley Cloud is pretty busy running around getting a petition signed trying to put me out of my job. Now I wish to tell you that these Henry girls are bad girls. They are on the roads every night and they stay around Ravenswood all hours on Saturday nights. I don't think it is right that some of the Indians should uphold such girls. Besides the Henry's are not members of the band.

Myrtle Henry (the girl I had so much trouble with) is a daughter of George Henry, a brother of Rachel's. He is not married to the woman he is living with. Lucy Cloud is Belle Cloud's wife of Uncle Fritz, Stanley's father. If the Indian Department would investigate circumstances, they would find a lot of queer things going on. And I do not think that they would heed to such people. I am just informing you there stories. Hoping that you would not believe what they say. They are picking at me all the time anyway. M. Paul says that.
I work hard helping in every thing on the reserve—but the Henry's never do anything only making trouble—You just ought to see some of the base writing on the wall outside of our school house—it is just awful—It was the girls that did it.

Mrs. Harris.—I also wish to ask you if there is any chance of a change—I like to go to some other reserve if I can't go school. I think I can get along far better among strangers—I am related to nearly everybody around here except the Brevoets—And I think that is why they do not care for me—I got to do something for my living—as my husband is not doing—he can do the chores but no hard work and it is up to me to earn the living for both two—I am in a fix too—because my home is here—I am tied right down—unless I sell out.—And I do not like to do that.

I do not wish to have the Indians know that I have written to you—I am afraid they might all pile on to me—I like to keep on teaching for a few more years—if they would only leave me alone—but it seems that they can't do that.
Another thing I wish to mention or inquire about. Mr. Abraham said something to me some time ago about a Summer School up at Bracebridge. I would like to know what arrangement could be made so I could attend same during summer holidays.

Miss Emma Brown (my husband's niece) is willing to come and keep house for me, if I went. She is a teacher at Moray near Parkhill.

Will you be kind enough to inform me about this School? I will be very much pleased if you will, as I have decided to go if I get a chance.

I remain

Your Truly,

E. L. M. Kinmore

Dear Mr. Elliott:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, with reference to a petition from local Indians concerning Mrs. R. McKinnon, teacher of the Stone Point Indian Bay School. I may say that this teacher is related to several residents on the reserve and has difficulty keeping out of local squabbles. The result is that certain Indians are trying to secure her dismissal.

Mrs. McKinnon herself, feels that the situation is so trying that she would like a transfer and the Department is keeping her wish in this respect in mind. As far as her ability as a teacher is concerned, I wish to state that the public school inspector has reported quite favourably on her work and on the progress of the pupils. The average attendance is good, a percentage of approximately 75, which is remarkably high for an Indian day school.

I note that you have been told a number of the children are unable to go to school and that conditions are rather bad on the reserve. I regret that I am unable to report in this connection, as I do not know what children and what conditions are in the mind of your informant.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

When Mr. McQuiggen was here last week he mentioned his thought that on the resignation of Miss Anderson of the Stony Point school becoming effective the school might be amalgamated with mine. I understand that he intended to discuss the matter with you. I have thought the matter over in the interval and this letter is motivated solely by my interest in the life of the reserve.

While I feel that a school of six or seven pupils - the more especially where the average attendance is poor - is definitely anti-social, we have had an experience on this reserve in church amalgamation which has failed dismally. I am certain that this happened because the people concerned were never approached but were given an arbitrary decision by the churches concerned. I have a feeling that the same would happen if a union of the schools were attempted without putting the matter to the parents concerned before a ruling was given by the Department. I further feel that this should not be attempted by those within the Agency but by a representative of your Department.

I have lived very close to these people and know them - perhaps largely through the community work that we do in the evening - and have come to be fairly accurate in judging their reactions.

If, however, the parents (and this applies to the Stony Point people) could be shown that their children actually suffer by the continuance of the small school, I consider that the plan has infinite merit.

There is the matter of transportation. The schools are approximately four miles apart, but with the exception of perhaps an half mile from this school to the highway the entire distance is Provincial Highway and should be open throughout the year. The road on our reserve is seldom blocked. It would mean one of two things as I see it, either the teacher or some responsible person
would have to be in charge of the transportation. If attendance has been a problem at Stoney Point, and I understand that the average attendance is low, I am inclined to doubt the wisdom of allotting the transportation to an Indian. I feel that the teacher would probably be the best person unless a farmer in the vicinity could be secured. I am doubtful of this because it would mean two breeds in his district all times of the year and he would have to be given the authority of a truant officer. Either the teacher might use his or her own car on a mileage basis, or the department might prefer to purchase a car for this purpose. This latter would necessitate the building of a garage here.

The saving should be of sufficient amount to make the idea appealing to the Department. The transportation should be really the only expense as compared to the maintenance of the school at present.

With certain small adjustments this school is capable of taking on as many as ten extra pupils I should say.

If, on the other hand, you feel the school should be maintained I would like to mention another matter. I have felt that the teachers of these two schools might conveniently share the residence here. The distance is comparatively small and the expense would be less than boarding I think. This would allow of combined and concerted work on the part of the two workers. If I am to remain here this arrangement would be quite satisfactory to me, although I would like someone who is used to -- shall I say the amenities of life.

I hope that you will pardon my intrusion into this matter, but as I have said, I feel that it concerns a work in which I have a deep interest.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

In the first nine years I was the only teacher in the district, and the number of pupils was from 55 in 1926 to 86 in 1934. At one time seven nationalities were represented—at all times five, and at least six church groups.

The photo forwarded herewith was taken in 1934 when I was teaching nine grades with over 80 pupils.

No reason was given me for my dismissal a few months after a two-roomed school had been built. It has been the policy of Ukrainian schools for years to replace teachers of English-speaking races with teachers of their own nationality.

This application has been delayed because I have been unable to locate all the copies I have made of inspectors' reports. I am sending
two that I have, and can, if necessary, apply to my last inspector for a further statement. An independent estimate as to the efficiency of my teaching may be procured from the principals of them or will and therefore, respectfully, when some of my children have been attending since the end of February last. My children had from me no instruction in school work other than the regular class work.

I may say that I am a life-long abstainer from both intoxicants and tobacco, but I am not in the habit of condemning or criticizing those who use these things.

I shall be glad to have the enclosed returned at your convenience.

I am,

Yours sincerely and respectfully,

Harry Tomlin

PERSONAL REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF MARCH, 1941.

X X X

SCHOOLS

I have visited all schools in the Agency and will continue my reports on the progress as I find it. You will remember in my report for the month of February I said I was disappointed. I am still a little disappointed with Kettle & Stony Point schools. I do not attribute this entirely to the teachers although I think sometimes they get a little discouraged. The percentage of children with any inclination to learn is small. The others show an utter disregard. I had a long talk with Mr. Howard, the teacher of Kettle Point School, and he tells me he has been taking a mental I.Q. of the Indians at Kettle Point School and he finds they have an average of sixty. Whether or not this is an excuse, I am not prepared to say. I am of the opinion that more effort should be made to memorize their work. It is appalling! You go over a lesson thoroughly—you ask the class a question—give them the answer—review the lesson in the next five minutes and they can't answer.

Kettle Point was the dumpy school for the month of February. Stony Point showed some signs of improvement although I think they had concentrated on Lambton Country the whole month. But even at that if progress can be made we are at least accomplishing a little. The children at St. Clair are so much more advanced and have a good knowledge of their lessons. With the exception of two or three, any question is readily answered although I am told the Provincial Inspector's report on St. Clair School is not very good. I am inclined to think there is a little vindictiveness in his reports. He and Mr. Smith have claimed on occasions I thought of asking Mr. Howard and Mr. Tompkins to outline their lessons in the form of stories. It may help them to memorize, and instead of attempting a general knowledge, to concentrate on one subject until they have learned it thoroughly. What think you? Or would it interfere with the school curriculum as laid down by the Provincial? Reading and arithmetic can be clasped about the same—St. Clair quite good, Kettle & Stony Point fair to bad. The writing in all schools is exceptional. There are some beautiful writers. This only tends to strengthen my opinion on manual and vocational training. They see something through the eye and catch on quickly. Writing, painting, drawing, whittling with a jack knife or similar tools of any kind are some of the things they love to do; but give them a mathematical or geographical lesson and they are not interested. Compared with February, I would say there is a little improvement.

X X X

PERSONAL REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF APRIL, 1941.

SCHOOLS:

All schools in the Agency have been visited and continuing my reports on the monthly tests. I am happy to report decided improvement.

St. Clair school on the Sarnia Reserve with Mr. Robert Smith as teacher has been outstanding. Since the start of these tests the children have responded wonderfully, even the very lowest grades showed a marked improvement. Their ready answers to almost every question asked is amazing when one realizes that only a few months ago they would stumble over the simplest question.

Kettle Point School with Mr. Howard as teacher has also shown improvement. At this school I was particularly impressed with the subject of "silent reading". The subject of course, is not new but it is the first time I had heard it in an Indian School. I am enclosing a sample paper on the work. The answers given by the children were 80 to 100% correct. The higher grades also showed improvement, especially in geography. Mr. Howard informs me he notices the children coming from homes where they have radios are better informed. They often ask about particular countries they have heard mentioned and to have them pointed out on the map. Arithmetic at this school showed good improvement.

Stanley Point School with Mr. Tompkins as teacher is lagging behind. I would not say this is the fault of the teacher, but rather a lack of cooperation. A school of this type with its small number on the roll and an average attendance of 50% is most difficult and I am sure Mr. Tompkins is, at times, discouraged and feels his efforts are not appreciated.

I have again discussed the question of monthly tests with the teachers in an endeavour to discover the reaction of the children, also the parents. They all agree that the children are very interested and express the wish that it had been started before. Mr. Smith asked one little fellow why he was talking to himself. He said, "I want to tell the Mr. Agent that".

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter 29-3-1 of May 21st, 1942, in connection with the moving of the Stony Point School to Kettle Point to provide a dwelling for one of the Indian families from Stony Point.

Recently I was told by some of the Indians that this school was built about fifty years ago by the Indians who supplied the lumber themselves and also performed the labour. The Department apparently did not expend any appropriated funds in the original erection of this building. The Indians therefore, that this building is Band property in spite of the fact that the Department has spent a considerable sum in upkeep and repairs during the past several years.

Mrs. Joseph White of the Kettle Point Band is expecting us to move the school for her future use as a house. This Indian woman is at present occupying a brick house which cannot be moved and which has to be pulled down most immediately. Unless otherwise advised, I intend to have the school moved and remodelled to provide a house for Mrs. White. In view of the fact that the Band claim ownership, should consent from the Band be secured before the school is moved. If so, kindly advise. Also advise if the Band is entitled to compensation for what they consider is their property.

There are numerous other problems relating to the school such as the transportation to Kettle of the wood which is on hand at Stone School. I am endeavouring to locate storage space for the school equipment but this is also a problem. I expect that I shall have to engage a team or truck to move the wood and school desks. A voucher in payment will have to be submitted to the Department when this work has been completed.
I thought I should mention now the matter of accommodation for pupils at Kettle next Fall. The children who are moving from Stony to Kettle will probably overtax the present school at Kettle Point and result in a serious problem of adequate accommodation in future. It is also possible that the present teacher, Mr. Howard, who has a large attendance already, will refuse to teach so many additional children. It is expected that accommodation for approximately fifteen extra children will be required at the Kettle Point school next October. At this time it would be next to impossible to obtain building materials if an addition to the Kettle Point school became necessary on account of increased attendance.

In view of the above it might perhaps be wise to consider all angles before the present Stony school is definitely abandoned. In the event that the Department decides to retain this building for use as a school at Kettle other arrangements would have to be made for a house for Mrs. White and I should be immediately advised providing such action is contemplated.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken, Indian Agent.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of July 29th,

I have carefully looked over the blue print and made a bill of materials in accord with the plans viz., studding, sills, rafters etc. and I can get an Indian quite capable of doing the work but I would have to buy the materials and pay him by the day. I can get the lumber cheap for the time and place at $1.50 per ft. So the whole job as nearly as I can estimate in advance would cost about $2000. To wit $1250 for lumber and hardware (nails and hinges etc.) and $750 for teaming and labor. I think if everything goes right it will be done for less but not very much so that may safely be accepted as approximate.

With regard to the water supply, I cannot report as satisfactorily as I would like. The school house at Stony Point is about two miles from the lake (Lake Huron) and the steep descent in the level of the country is between. The soil there is clay and there does not seem any certainty or even a good chance of getting a good supply by digging. The Indians when asked about the water can give no information. Most of them have just surface wells, do them fairly well for a small supply. They give all kind of answer when asked how far it is to the rock vary from 15 feet to 60 and said some neighbor there had bored to the rock and got salt water. Still I think if anything is done to is what to do - as in all this section of country boring to the rock furnishes a plentiful supply of hygienically wholesome water and is the only permanent source of supply. Well water are easily got - and should not for that depth cost over $5?

I have made an estimate of the cost of a cement or concrete foundation for the Stony Point school. I may say first that this will be necessary in a year or two at the latest. It will do all right this year but it is standing on wooden block which have been in for over ten years. I believe ever since that school was built and they cannot last much longer. An concrete idea is that it would make the school more comfortable besides being permanent.

I submitted the matter to the Butteridge Co. here. Being at Stony Point it is out of their reach for contracting but the manager was kind enough to go into all the details with me and gave me his prices for everything. For 1½ feet under ground and 32 inches of cement blocks which is the most common and modern above ground, his estimate is $85.00. This allows for a wall 1 foot wide below the surface of good concrete pounded in the usual way and cement blocks - 4 rows. Blocks $8.75

This estimate I think is high. Sand and gravel is handy there and by bringing the under wall a little higher and allowing for joint 8 rows of blocks would do as well as four. This we easily make it 36 inches high which would be all right.
Sir,

Referring to your letter of No.

I also consulted a cement worker who has had a good deal of experience though not now in the business - and like me he thinks the Butteridge Co.'s estimate is high. I think by making the alteration I suggest I can strike off ten dollars. Also I do not know of any body in that neighborhood who makes cement blocks.

If cement blocks are not used - it will take ten cubic yards of concrete which should be put in there for $6.75 per cubic yard.

I like the block plan best myself and if they can be got handy they are not any dearer than last estimate & allows for the same height about 30 or 32 inches above ground.

I am

Your obedient servant,
William Hallett
Indian agent

As far as I know this is the whole. There might be a few cents for a mortar board, but as the lumber will be used in putting up the wood shed it will not be charged to the foundation. This is inside the estimated cost but owing to the difficulty in raising up and supporting the old house as well as the great height it would make it preferable to the width of the building what is 14 feet. Also we have 3 rows of blocks instead of four as was contemplated. There is enough money in the appropriation to have done it 5 & 6 blocks being required for a sound, but there is no doubt it is plenty high enough now. Up the floor is almost 3 feet including all of building from the normal level of the ground. There was no provision for door stops but they are put in and are included in the Page account. The frame work being made of cement blocks. I have not yet seen the job since it was finished, but I have personally purchased the cement and made the bargain with Mr. Page and looked over the raising up of the building and profiting it off and was there when the men put in the concrete under the surface and made the trenches & put it in. I do not think if I had let it would have been done at all unless by contracting which I was not to do as Butteridge in Sarnia wanted freight paid and transportation and drayage from Sheldrake and thus was no contractor in the business who at Story Point which is over
thirty miles from Sarnia. Mr. Pugsley is reasonable being 12 cents each for blocks including the mason work & providing cement for the mortar. John Elijah when he has any body to buy the material and tell him in detail what it is a good assistant and I am satisfied that the work will be durable and satisfactory.

Until the foundation was in it was impossible to erect the lean-to wood-shed but I have arranged to have this done now. Hoping this is all satisfactory.

On the 2nd inst., I received a communication from Mr. Thomas Parkinson of Thedford, stating that John Elijah said it would take about Thirteen Dollars for material to paint the school house and the roof would require to be shingled, as it leaked; that shingles were Four Dollars per thousand and that he could get the work done any time.

This was previous to the meeting of the Council which convened at Kettle Point the 6th inst., composed, as you are aware, almost entirely of new members. I replied to Mr. Parkinson, asking him to let me know what the cost of painting the school house inside and out and shingling it would be. He was away from home and I received no reply.

On the 14th inst., I was called up by John Elijah who stated that he was shingling the school house. He had one half done and had secured the paint for the purpose of painting. I said, "Why, who authorized you to do anything like that? I have just been waiting for a communication giving me some idea of the cost of the work with a view of forwarding it to the Department and asking for instructions." He simply said, "Why, the Council said it was to be done, and the roof leaks and it has to be done." I said, "You know the Council has no authority to order work done in that way" and his reply was simply, "Well, it had to be done", so I had simply to drop him.

I then received a letter from Mr. Parkinson saying, "I met John Elijah today and he informs me that the shingles cost $19.00 and labour of putting them on, $4.50, carrying (that means no doubt, teaming them from Thedford) $2.00, painting material $12.50, labour $7.00, adding, I understand, "The roof will be completed tonight and the painting will be commenced at once."

Of course, as stated above, this is all irregular and doubtless the new Council, not being guided by the old members, thought that they were at liberty to proceed in this way. Unfortunately, I was too ill at the time to attend the Council which I regretted very much, but it is evident the
Sir,

work was all necessary, the painting needed and the roof indispensable, so, I would be glad if the Department could overlook this irregularity and as soon as I am satisfied that the work is done and properly done, and the prices fair, I will make out vouchers and send them forward.

Trusting this explanation will be satisfactory.

I am, Sir,

Agent.
I am taking this opportunity to bring to your attention the necessity for a new school building at Kettle Point.

The present school house is altogether too small for the number enrolled. The desks are crowded too closely together and it is necessary in some instances to seat three pupils at one double desk. The building itself is old and rather than spend any money on repairs it would be advisable to erect a new school with teacher's residence included.

The parents are taking more interest in sending their children to school and are anxious to have better accommodation.

In this connection it would be as well to give some consideration to a central school for the two reserves. From a casual survey of the situation, I think that this is a matter which Schools Branch should give careful consideration. There are never more than ten or eleven pupils at Stony Point School. This seems to be too few to warrant the expense of upkeep of teacher's salary. The Stony Point school would be better situated if built up on the hill, near the church. This would bring it much closer to Stony Point reserve and an arrangement could probably be made for transportation of pupils daily to the school and return. I mention this only as a suggestion for consideration and not as a proposition, which has been given careful thought. I do, however, strongly recommend a new school for Kettle Point reserve and that the location be changed to a more central point.

Mrs. Ferries,
Dept. of Indian Schools,

I have to write a few lines to you regarding our school and children.

The children are very much dissatisfied on account of the new school at Kettle Pt. Reserve. They think it is very unfair to give everything to Kettle Pt. and we do not get a thing for our school. They are positive that the attendance would be larger if we had a different school house. I know myself it would be so much nicer if our school was a little larger and if we had a bell besides. Most of the pupils come in so late and it is impossible to follow the program the way we should. I think it would make a lot of difference if we had a bell and about twenty single desks.

I expect to have three signatures for help right away, and I have not the room unless I put two in a seat and I do not like that. I do sincerely wish that the Indian Dept. grant us the seats and the bell, if we cannot get a new school.

There are a lot of little children on the reserve and in two or three years time, this little school house will not hold them all.

I hope I am not asking too much; I am writing this letter to please the pupils because they are at me every day to write. I would be very much pleased if we can get the seats & the bell. Trusting you will consider this matter and grant us our request.

I remain,

Mrs. Ruth M. King

Ottawa, December 24, 1929.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McCookin, in a report on his visit to the Stony Point Indian Day School, states that a small porch at the front entrance is badly needed to provide cloakroom space and warmth during the winter months. He states that there is only a single door which opens directly into the classroom, making it cold and draughty, and that there is no place for the pupils' coats and hats. If weather conditions permit, I have to request that you will arrange to have a small porch erected at the front entrance, with space for cloakroom purposes. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to see that a suitable porch is erected, and at the least possible expense, having in view the carrying out of a satisfactory job. You should arrange to have this work carried out as soon as it is possible to have it done.

The Inspector states that the front steps are completely worn out, but if this porch is erected, the steps can be done away with.

He also states that the boys' closet needs a new screen, and that a urinal should be installed, also that a wood box should be provided for the classroom and that the chimney should be pointed to secure some loose bricks, and that the board walk over the culvert at the road entrance is worn out and should be replaced at once. He further states that the front fence requires repairs and that the wire should be stretched and stapled.

You should arrange to have all the above repairs mentioned by the Inspector carried out. You should see that the work is satisfactorily completed, at as low a cost as possible.

The Inspector further recommends that a teacher's desk and chair be provided. You should obtain prices for the supplying of a desk and chair, and arrange for the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price. It is not intended that any expensive articles be supplied.

After all the above authorized work has been completed, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Ottawa, December 6th, 1929.

Sir:

I inspected the Sar ia Agency on the 20th and 21st ultimo and beg to submit the following report.

Stoney Point School is in charge of Miss Amy Landon, who has a second class certificate. There is a roll of twelve pupils. Eight were present on the afternoon of my visit. Miss Landon, who took up the work last September, appears to be well suited for the work; discipline in the classroom is very good.

This school is badly in need of paint and will deteriorate rapidly unless painted as soon as possible. The whole building is in poor condition and requires a number of minor repairs.

A small porch at the front entrance is badly needed, to provide cloakroom space and warmth during the winter months. There is only a single door opening directly into the classroom making it cold and draughty. There is no place for the pupils' hats and coats. The front steps are completely worn out. If the porch is built, the steps can be done away with.

The boys' closet needs a new screen and a urinal installed. A wood box should be provided for the classroom. The chimney should be pointed to secure some loose bricks. The front fence is sagged; it should be stretched and staples. The boardwalk over the culvert at the road entrance is worn out and should be replaced at once. A teacher's desk and chair should be provided. A dilapidated kitchen table is in use as a desk. Some broken window lights are being replaced and locks for the classroom cupboard and wood shed provided by Agent Paul. He is also attending to repairs to the school pump, which is out of order.

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector.
Ottawa, January 4, 1930.

Sir:

I would like to know if the Department would be in favour of providing a small amount of money for each school in this Agency so that hot lunches could be served at noon hour.

It could be very conveniently arranged at Kettle Pt., where the teacher's living quarters are connected with the school, also at Stony Pt., as the teacher takes her lunch, and something hot could be prepared on the school stove. At the St. Clair School it would require an extra expenditure to fix up a gas plate, as there is no stove for the children in the classroom.

I think it would be a good thing for the children if hot soup, etc., could be provided and would suggest that $5.00 be allowed Stony Pt. and $10.00 for the other schools, for supplies.

Trusting this will receive favourable consideration, and an early reply would be appreciated.

Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

During the first quarter of the current year this school was closed for four weeks because of an epidemic of "flu" and measles.

At the present time there are three admitted cases of scarlet fever from the school and many cases of cold etc., which are causing the absence of the pupils concerned.

Keeping these facts in mind and from observation of the lunches brought to school, I suggest that the increase in illness over past years may be partially attributable to under-nourishment.
This condition might be rectified to some extent by serving some form of hot lunches at noon hour.

It would be necessary to install some sort of stove or gas plate in the school. The children would probably be willing to supply their own dishes etc.

In the only other school from which I have been able to secure any data, the cost of food per pupil was $1.50 per meal for the winter of 1932-33. In this case they served a bowl of vegetable and meat stew, one slice of bread and a cup of cocoa or milk.

I am fully aware of the need for economy at the present time and will not feel in any sense aggrieved if you take no action in this matter. I am Sir,

Your obedient servant

Hon. E. Hindbree

Some of the cement blocks in the foundation are loose as the mortar has fallen away and the blocks are very easily pushed out of position.

The outbuildings are not in very good shape, but I think with a few minor repairs and a thorough cleaning, they will do for another year. Any work authorized can be done by Indians, the cost kept as low as possible and should not exceed $40.00.

The Kettle Point School has been painted but authority has not yet been obtained for cleaning well, repairing and cleaning the outbuildings.

Trusting to be favoured with an early reply.

Your obedient servant,

J.C. McCormick

The Stoney Point School is in poor condition
and too small. The classroom is 18 X 23, average
attendance eight, eleven on the roll. There are ten
double seats, badly worn and too large for the pupils.
The building needs painting inside and out. The two
closets are past repairing and should be replaced

Ottawa, October 29, 1935.

SIR:

In a report on his recent inspection of the Stony Point Indian Day School, Inspector McGeckin states there are 10 double seats badly worn and too large for the pupils. He states, further, that the inside and outside of the building should be painted and that the two closets should be replaced, as they are past repairing.

Regarding the desks, I would request that you take up this matter with the teacher, with a view to ascertaining the size and the number of each size of single school desks required to provide adequate seating accommodation at this school. In arranging the seating, it would be advisable to have one row of the same size desk with a front and rear seat. When the Department receives the information requested above, consideration will be given as to whether funds can be provided to supply new desks this year.

With reference to the replacing of the closets, I would request that you will furnish particulars regarding the type and size of closets you would recommend and the approximate cost of material and labour in the erection. Please state, also, if you consider these closets should be built this fall.

There will be no funds available to paint the exterior and interior of the school building this year. Early next spring, you should report regarding this matter, stating what painting you would recommend be done and the cost of material and labour.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. C. McCormick, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
S A R N I A, Ont.
Forest, Nov 25, 1935.

Mr. A. F. MacKenzie,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

After careful consideration of the size and needs of the children and a study of Hendry's catalogue I decided that the most satisfactory seats would be 5 Preston 85C single desks size 2 priced $7.75 each and a Kindergarten Primary table No. C priced $5.50 with 6 chairs No. 57 at $1.40 making a total of $26.65. These seats are adjustable and the children are small. We have a larger Primary than Senior Department as the children leave school at an early age.

Before replacing the seats the floor will have to be repaired as there are large cracks between the boards and Mr. McHutchin spoke of removing the platform at the front of the room.

The closets are neither safe nor sanitary. The estimate made by Conlee Lumber Co in Shedden was $45 for
material. I have been unable to obtain an estimate for the labour but I believe they could be erected in 5 days at $2 a day.

Yours truly,

Mary E. Anderson,
Forest, Ont.

Sir:- Re: Stony Point Indian Day School,

The covering on the wall at this school is not in a very safe condition and I have given instructions to have a new top put on it at once. I trust this meets with your approval.

The Teacher, Miss Anderson has requested permission to employ a man for a few days to put the flower beds and grounds in shape for the winter. As the pupils are all young they cannot do this themselves and I would recommend this be done. The cost should not exceed $10.00.

Regarding the school building itself. The foundation seems to be alright but the frame of the building is settling towards the front or entrance. Evidently when constructed it was never properly braced. The front of the building is now three or four inches out of plumb, at the top, with the result that the doors and cupboard doors do not fit well and are hard to open and close. The building should also be painted inside and out next year.

I think it would be advisable to have whoever comes up for the Fall Pay make a report on this building.

Your obedient servant,

November 30th, 1936.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my inspection of the Sarnia Agency on the 12th-13th instant.

The Agency is composed of the Sarnia Reserve and Kettle and Stony Point Reserves.

The Stoney Point School has been greatly improved with a new floor and new single seats. The attendance is poor. There are seven on the roll with an average attendance of four. I could find no reason for this only indifference. The parents have been warned time and again by the R.C.M.P. Police to send their children regularly, they attend for a few days and drop right back again. The same applies to the Kettle Point School.

There are a few parents who have persistently neglected to send their children to school. I would recommend that the school attendance regulations be enforced on the Kettle & Stoney Point Reserves and that the Agent be authorized to proceed against the delinquent parents. With the two well equipped schools and efficient teachers provided for their benefit right at their door, it is too bad that these boys and girls should be permitted to face life without the advantages of some education.

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector.

Jan. 15th, 1937.

Sir:

On my visit to the Stony Point Indian Day School, yesterday Miss Anderson the Teacher informed me that during the holidays someone had broken into the school and woodshed. They entered by breaking a window in the school and also broke the lock off the woodshed. Nothing appears to have been taken, although they had a fire on in the stove. It looks as if it were done by some of the local boys. The Mounted Police are investigating the case at present and Corp. Chisholm informs me he expects to locate the guilty parties shortly.

I gave instructions to have another pane of glass put in and another lock put on the woodshed, which I trust meets with your approval.

I will report any further developments in the case as soon as possible.

January 13, 1939

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter under date of Jan. 10th, re 5¢ delivery charge on milk supplied Stony Point Indian Day School, I have taken this matter up with Mr. Tompkins, the teacher, and he reports the farmer in question will not deliver the milk to the school at 10¢ per quart, which is the standard price per quart in this section of the country. Hence the 5¢ for delivery charge, which is given to a little Indian boy for delivering the 3 quarts of milk daily.

Last year Mr. Tompkins was boarding at this particular farm house and carried the milk to school with him. Previous years Miss. Anderson drove past this farm house on her way to school every morning and picked the milk up. This accounts for the charge not being made in former years.

Extract from Inspector J.J. Edwards' report on the Stoney Point Indian Day School visited on December 7, 1939.

The lighting of the classroom is quite poor on dull days. There are only four small windows of about 8 square feet each for a floor space of approximately 360 square feet. Better results would be secured if the west side were renovated so as to admit the maximum amount of light. The interior of the class room needs repainting. There is only one chair. Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Stoney Point Indian Day School on December 7 last Inspector Edwards writes as follows:

"The lighting of the classroom is quite poor on dull days. There are only four small windows of about 8 square feet each for a floor space of approximately 360 square feet. Better results would be secured if the west side were renovated so as to admit the maximum amount of light. The interior of the classroom needs repainting. There is only one chair. Ventilation would improve if sloping boards were placed at the base of the windows so that the incoming air would be directed upward and warmed before reaching the children's heads."

On the occasion of your next visit to the school you should ascertain the approximate cost of making the improvements suggested by the Inspector and advise the Department.

It will not be possible to provide funds for any repairs or improvements at this school between now and the end of March but if you recommend the improvements suggested by the Inspector and their cost is reasonable it may be possible to secure the necessary funds from the appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41.

Yours truly,

Mr. Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent,
Sarnia, Ont.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
SARNIA, Ontario,
February 16, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Re: Stony Point Indian Day School

Your File No. 29-3-5

Replying to your letter under date of February 8, 1940, I visited the school referred to on February 15. After a careful survey, I submit my comments on Inspector Edward's suggested improvements.

The school is a very small building and quite old as noted by the approximate square feet of space. It is built north and south with two windows, each 29" by 53", on either side, east and west. Mr. Tompkins informs me the day Mr. Edwards visited the school it was very dull and naturally a school of this type would be dull and uninteresting. The day I called was a nice bright day and the appearance was altogether different. However, I have pointed out before that the interior of this school is badly in need of decoration. As far as the windows are concerned, unless you are prepared to tear the side walls down it cannot be changed. In any case it would not be an recommendation. The building does not warrant such an expenditure. I asked the teacher if he found any difficulty from any angle in the room in reading the blackboards. He reports no. I had the children reading small letters from every angle with satisfaction. I also asked the teacher and the children if they found it dull or hard on the eyes. They didn't think so.

There are 2 chairs, 6 kindergarten chairs, 15 desks, 1 teacher's desk, 2 tables, 1 sand table, 1 work bench, 1 organ, and 9 pupils, on this floor space of approximately 540 ft. What they would do with even one more chair in such
Re: Stony Point Indian Day School.

a small room, I do not know. I think if the classroom was redecorated, it would add greatly to the appearance and, to a certain extent, improve the light. It would cost approximately $75 to do this work. However, if you decided to increase the window space, it would possibly cost $300 to $350. You would still have an old lopsided building.

Trusting this will assist in determining your actions, I am,

Your obedient servant,

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.

T. R. L. MacInnes, Esq.,
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Canada.
Dear Sir:

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 16th instant the Department considers it inadvisable to change the windows in the Stony Point Indian Day School.

Owing to the recent dissolution of the House I am not in a position at the present time to state definitely what amount will be available for repairs and improvements at Indian day schools during the fiscal year 1940-41. However, I hope that it will be possible to provide the amount of $75.00 required for decorating the interior of this school. You might write to me again in this matter early in June in order that, if funds are available, the work can be done during the summer holidays.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Your letter under date of June 24, 1940, with reference to interior decorating of Stony Pt. Indian Day School, received.

It is rather difficult, at this time, to define the expenses in connection with the said decorations. The school in question will need some painting, some repairs to the woodwork; also labour costs. SARNIA, Ontario,
October 27, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of October 20, 1941, in reference to a Well at Stony Point School.

The Wells, both at Stony Point and Kettle Point, have given cause for annoyance and while cleaning out would perhaps help, it would only be temporary. They are both surface water wells and will contaminate every year. The only way to correct the situation would be to drill new wells. As far as Stony Point is concerned the possibility of getting water would be good, but in the case of Kettle Point I am doubtful.

However, if you are agreeable to have the Wells cleaned, I will get estimates and submit for your consideration. I would also mention that both Wells need new pumps. Should this also meet with your approval, I will submit estimates with the cost of cleaning.

Your obedient servant,

Geo. W. Down,

REPORT ON SARNIA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF AUGUST, 1944.

Work on the erection of the new classroom at Kettle Point Indian Day School progressed quite favourably in August. Unfortunately no lumber company in this locality has any hardwood flooring. If we had been able to get the flooring the building would have been finished by the end of August. Most firms have it on order but have little or no idea when their shipments will arrive. It is now apparent that the new classroom will not be ready when school reopens on September 5.

M.W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

Referring to the resolution of the Sarnia Indian Council of the 1st instant to have one acre of land at Stony Point reserved for school and church purposes, I have to request you to be good enough to send a description by Metes and bounds of the piece of land referred to and also show its position on a sketch. Sarnia Reserve, April 5th, 1911.

Chief Menass presided for half an hour until Agent R.C. Palmer came, who was unavoidably detained.

Moved by Chief E. Menass seconded by Jabez Nah-mabin that one acre of land at Stony Point a part lot occupied by Wm. Johnston be set apart for school and church purposes and the occupant be paid the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for the said one acre of land. Carried.

Moved and seconded to adjourn.

(Sgn) F.W. Jacobs,

Ottawa, April 19, 1911.

Sir,

Referring to a resolution of the Sarnia Indian Council of the 5th instant to the effect that $10.00 be paid to Mr. Johnson for one acre of land at Stony Point which is required for school purposes, I have to request you to be good enough to comply with the instructions contained in letter to you of the 17th February last, and to forward your report thereon as soon as you conveniently can.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Aest. Deputy and Secretary.

R. G. Palmer, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sarnia, Ont.
Referring to yours of 17th Feb., last.

When at Stony Point on the 26th April I took measurements of the acre desired as a lot for the school-house on which also the church stands and have prepared a plan, which I enclose herewith and trust it will be sufficiently intelligent to meet with the requirements.

My idea of describing the lot is as follows:- Beginning at a point 153 feet from the line between lot 2 range A and lot one range B to where a post has been planted; thence easterly along the high-way 292 feet to a point where a post has been planted; thence northerly 149 feet to a point where a post has been planted; then westerly 292 feet to a point where a post has been planted; thence southerly to the place of beginning.

This encloses an acre of land all but a fraction and seems to meet the requirements. I don't know that there is anything further that I can say with reference to this matter that will assist in preparing the necessary papers.

You will be good enough to instruct me at your earliest convenience.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

When visiting the Stony Point Indian Day School on March 12, 1942, the teacher, Mr. Tompkins, advised me that he has not procured any Manual Training or Sewing equipment during the 1941-42 school term.

Apparently Mr. Phelan verbally authorized the expenditure for this purpose when he attended the convention at Moraviantown last fall. The teacher of the Kettle Point School spent $20.00 to purchase Vocational Supplies but Mr. Tompkins has not made any expenditures for this purpose.

As lumber and other materials for teaching this important work are completely exhausted at the Stony Point School, I would recommend that the Department authorize an expenditure of $10.00 so that this work may be carried on for the balance of the 1942 term. This amount should be sufficient as there is only a small attendance at Stony Point School.

I would suggest that the Department approve of local purchase and accounts for materials supplied would be submitted under cover of a voucher for payment.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa 16th July 1896:

Rev: Sir,

I have the honor to inform you that, owing to the unsatisfactory manner in which the schools of the St Regis Band of Indians have hitherto been carried on, the Department has at the request of the Indians decided to continue only one school on Cornwall Island, in lieu of the Methodist and Roman Catholic Schools formerly carried on at that place, which will be conducted as a purely undenominational school. The Department will, however, gladly consent to religious instruction being given to pupils of your faith, at certain fixed time in the morning or after as best suits the convenience of your missionary in charge.

I may add that this affords the only solution of the difficulty regarding the schools on Cornwall Island, as the Indians have absolutely refused to make any further contributions from their funds for the support of two schools at that place.

Your obedient servant,

of Indian Affairs.

Sir,

In an interview which the Rev Dr Carman had with the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs early in November, the case of the Methodist Indian day school on Cornwall Island was referred to. I had previously given Dr Carman a brief memo of the facts in the case, and I think that memo was left with the Superintendent General. As it seems absolutely essential that the Methodist school should be reopened, I sincerely hope that the Indian Department has favorably considered the question of a grant, and I trust that the item will be included in the estimates to be laid before Parliament.

I am, Sir,

Yours Obedient Servant,

THE SECRETARY,

With reference to the letter from the Rev. Dr. Sutherland urging that a salary be provided for in the next estimates for the re-opening of the Methodist School on Cornwall Island, I beg to remind you that until the end of the school year 1895 there were two schools on Cornwall Island, one under the Roman Catholic Church, the other under the Methodists; but at that time it was considered that it would be advisable to combine these two schools into one common school, which was done. Dear Sir:-

We were speaking to your agent here on behalf of Mr. H. J. Walsh, late teacher at the Indian Reserve. Mr. Hagan did not seem inclined to discuss the matter, as he said his duty was simply to report on the amount of work done by Mr. Walsh.

It appears that Mr. Walsh started at the commencement of the term with the expectation of teaching for the year, and the fact that school was closed before the first month of the second quarter had expired has placed Mr. Walsh in rather bad position financially. He has a large family of small children, and his opportunity of getting another school will be very slim before the commencement of next year, and we take the liberty to write you on his behalf, calling attention to the fact that this is a real hardship to Mr. Walsh, and unless he gets a payment for more than the actual days taught, his family will suffer.

We have known Mr. Walsh since he started to teach here, and owing to his numerous family he has been obliged to live up to his income, and we trust you will excuse the liberty we take in thus writing you on his behalf. This is written from no pecuniary motive on our part, but simply from a desire to see Mr. Walsh leniently dealt with.

While your agent here might not feel disposed to discuss the matter from a business standpoint, we feel sure that his feelings of humanity would prompt him to report in favor of Mr. Walsh receiving a full quarter's pay.

Yours respectfully,

Mr. Scott,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I just returned a few days ago from the Les Sables Indian reserve, which is about five miles from Thessalon.

While I was there the Indians came to me wanting a teacher this year on their reserve.

There are eleven children there of school age and the closest school to the reserve is about two miles and a half. They said it was too far for their children to go to school. In fact only one attended school last year and that was for about two months of the school term.

They asked me if I would give them my chapel there for a school house, which I willingly agreed to, so all they really need is a teacher and the necessary books. The desks from the old school are still in good order.

The Indians of that reserve came to me with a petition and a resolution which they had passed in their council to this effect. They were to take one copy to the agent Mr. Rothera at Thessalon and the other copy they asked me to send directly to the department. I am enclosing it in this letter.

I spoke to Mr. Rothera, the agent, about it and he said he would take the matter up with the department.

I also would like to have a teacher there if the department sees fit. None of the children are able to read or write except one or two who have attended Spanish school.

In the event of their not getting a teacher there, there will be five more applications for Spanish, so would you kindly let me know as soon as possible the decision of the Department regarding this matter so that I may get them to sign the applications for their entry to Spanish School.

I am leaving this P.M. for Sagamok and will be away for seven days through that reserve.

I was expecting a letter from you re- the Sagamok School.

Hoping to hear from you soon,

I am sincerely yours,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th inst., in reference to the reopening of the Thessalon River school.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is pleased to see that the Band has shown a desire to have their children educated, but it is considered too late in the season to undertake the erection of a new building, as when the work is done the Department would like to put up a modern school-house that will be a credit to the reserve. Any repairs necessary to make the old building habitable for the coming winter ought to be made at once; it is presumed that none of an extensive nature will be required. Sir,

I beg to advise you that the Department has increased the salary of Miss L. G. Shaddesu, teacher of the Thessalon Indian school, to $450.00 from the first of the current quarter. It has been reported to the Department that the school-house is in a poor condition, is very dirty and is in need of some repairs. This is a matter that should have been attended to by you during the summer holidays. As the school will be re-opened in a few days it will be necessary for you to take immediate steps to have the place thoroughly cleaned and any necessary repairs made. The Department must insist upon this work receiving immediate and careful attention.

A teacher's desk and chair being ordered to be sent to your address and you will be good enough to see that they are conveyed to the school when they arrive. A supply of fuel for use next winter should also be procured by you at an early date.

It is noted that your monthly reports upon this school have not been received. These will be expected commencing with the month of September next.

Arrangements to have the schoolroom cleaned regularly should be made and I would ask you to report me what could be done in this regard.

Miss Shaddesu has been authorized to purchase a dresser and some utensils and instructs you to forward accounts through you.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

It will take 200 feet of plank to make the platform which will cost $4.00. It will take a barrel of lime which will cost $1.50 and about $1.00 worth plaster Paris to finish.

There is a small piece of the ceiling fell in the class room and in one bed room it has nearly all fell down. We'll have to hire a team to take the material to the reserve which will cost me $4.00 and I think $4.00 ought to do the work which is $8.00. General Correspondence
School No. 3
Sir,

I have the honor to report of Mr. & Mrs. Smith's school at Wolf Island, Ontario, ending 30th September 1894. Mr. Smith, teacher.

With reference to the remarks on page 2 of the report, "That the school was interrupted from being closed on the 25th August after the holidays, on account of sickness being prevalent."

I have to report, that it was well known when the school closed for the holidays that there was sickness prevalent, and that during the holidays was the time to make them, so that the school house would be ready for occupation at the opening.

I wrote during the holidays, immediately to the Chief and the Members of the Council with respect to having this work done, told them at the opening after the holidays what work during these would have to be done at once, but must have the order of the Council to have it done, and the opinion of their body as to the extent of work required.
