Sir,

I have the honor to report that the schools on the Island were to be closed, and were, indeed, closed at 27th June, the summer holidays.

And in accordance with instructions contained in your letter No. 157945...A., dated 16th July, I beg to inform you that the former teacher Mr. Smith has been dismissed from his duties and will continue the position till the 3rd September next, or till the end of the September quarter, before which time he will receive no compensation.

He was quite willing that the school should be closed, but (the present) teacher wished to be appointed as stipulated by the Government.

The subject of his wife and mother, I had him with me last week five days during the Christmas holidays (but) was always kept with me at intermediate times when they visited their nearest relatives and could not well go with me. I visited him (myself) and only let him go this afternoon because he had to give the school.

I am now sorry that it became necessary to take the school away from him, having heard by him on several occasions that he was very much at the complaints against him being made in the interest of public morals, and because here the school seems like a lot of money that he had been carrying to carry, and they are so surely decided until the situation was brought and thought over a vacancy could be made whenever one of them (not half as good as this) could get.
Church which was to make a complaint that he had not a proper person to teach the school the former being that he was in the habit of getting drunk, instead of doing something to cheer himself or school days, and when they decided to get him out of the school he made complaints to the Indians and to the Department on the charge of drunkenness they began to press the parents mind and succeeded in such a way by designating the school that it was a question of a new teacher or close the school. Nevertheless he has been succeeded in convincing the Inspector. And the movement that he was a bad character in other ways than drinking, till there was nothing for it but to tell him he must give up the school and to give it at once as little man to be had as he was and is. But he signed and will not die. And while it will do him good, and therefore he has to have him if all hands are not taken from under him. And there are two hands which will try very hard to hold him in, as they have had to press the matter. We have him in the ground here done it for the best which purpose, upon once looking to the public morals part of the case, and where the young man Cornelius keeps his job with the No. 2 School (he could not be got) the Methodist Church people will not have the best man in the world to the lack of Indians.

Teacher of No. 3 school Arthur Macdonald has been in the habit of holding a concert & entertainment in his school & the proceeds he gets we do not know what he does with it.

So at last we serve him a notice that he will be no longer allowed to hold entertainments in his school. This reply said he was going to have them in spite of us.

Now is he allowed to carry on that way?

Some times fight takes place during the concerts & break up the desks.

We have three Halls on this Island purpose to hold shows & Concerts &c &c without having them in school houses & We would like to have the rules regulations written out to be guided by.

Kind enclosed bill so you can read for yourself.

School No. 3 Teacher turning out in his school.
Sometime ago you instructed our Indian Agent J. B. M. Campbell. Our Board must have at least district Certificate in order to teach school if they want to be kept paid for the year 1804. We wish this to be carried out end of this quarter.

We are the School Trustees of Wallace Hill and we are in favor the appointment of more efficient teachers holding the higher certificates. Our money been spent probably large enough spending good money for bad.

Let us hear from you at early date.

Yours truly,

Peter W. Thomas
Daniel Chauvin
Peter Willis

Secretary Dept of Indian Affairs

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 152945 dated 9th inst. reporting complaint of School Master that there has been only one entertainment held in this school house that I know of and did not know anything about it until the day before when one of the trustees Peter Thomas came to me and wanted to know if the school house could be used for that purpose. I told him that I did not know what the law was regarding Indian schools but that if the teacher felt he could hold any entertainments in the school house the teacher or Mr. Thomas came to see me about the matter. He said that Mr. John Barlow, a respectable citizen of St. Lambton had consented to bring a phonograph and give an entertainment to the children charging a fee of 10 cents each and giving half the proceeds to the children for the purpose of purchasing a football for use in the summer at school as the weather was cold and the council house quite a distance from the children so he thought that there would be no objections which was the reason that he had not consulted any person about the matter.

[Signature]

[Seal]
I told him that I did not know for sure who controlled the school houses, the chief and council or the agent, that if the chief had no objections I would not object as all arrangements had been made and it would be a disappointment to the children if they were not carried out from this end. I will tell you that the school houses are not used for any other purpose but for school. If it had been any of the other teachers I do not think their words would have any objections raised. The whole thing is a little while work. Misfortune was prevalent at the agricultural fair held here last fall and he strongly objected to Peter Shores one of the trustees holding a public dance in a field adjoining the fair grounds in opposition to a concert held by the band today and he thought it a good time to settle.

Sir,

I have the honor to submit the following report:

On September 25th, 1894, I presented the sum of $30.00 to pay the account of Mr. Joseph Wilson for planting, making blackboards, and repairing woodwork at the schoolhouse on Wallis Island.

With regard to the planting, there were several places where the plants had come up. However, due to the weather conditions, it was found that the whole of the plants might as well be replaced at once as they had all come up. It would be difficult to fix the plants where it was entirely off, and make any kind of a job of it. So it was decided to take them out and plant them anew at the time the school house was built. It was late in the fall, and the plants had evidently been frozen before it got dry, hence the coming off.

The blackboard had been condemned frequently by the students as too small; it was also cleared over the end of the school room, and there just five inches wide.

The work was ordered by the Chief and Council before it was commenced, and finished and delivered by them after it was finished. I feel so confident that it is a good job well done, and may be used for many years.

Yours sincerely,

MEMORANDUM:—
Law Clerk.

The Council of the Chippawas of the Thames passed a resolution authorizing the sale of the No. 3 school-house on the Reserve, which has not been in use for some years, to Mr. L. Dodge, a Pottawatamie Indian, for the sum of $275.00, $100.00 to be paid in cash and the balance in one year and a half. The Agent reports Mr. Dodge to be a sober industrious Indian and recommends the sale to him, but I think we should have some special form of agreement of sale prepared which would suit this particular case. The balance should be paid in three semi-annual installments.

Ottawa, October 23, 1911.
Agreement made this first day of November, one thousand nine hundred and eleven.

Between

The Council of the Chippewas of Walpole Island, in the Province of Ontario, hereinafter called the vendors of the first part

and

Mr. L. Dodge, a Potawatamie of the said Walpole Island, hereinafter called the purchaser of the second part

The vendors agree to sell and the purchaser agrees to purchase the building known as school house No. three on the Walpole Island Reserve for the sum of $275, payable as follows:- The sum of $100 upon the signing of this agreement and the balance in three instalments of $68.33 each payable on the first days of November and May, in each year until the full amount is paid; the first instalment of which shall be due and payable on the first day of May, one thousand nine hundred and twelve.

And it is hereby expressly provided that the purchaser shall have immediate possession of the said building and may remove it to his own premises, but the title to the said building shall remain in the vendors until the purchase price has been fully paid.

It is further provided that the purchaser shall not destroy the said building but will keep it in tact as a building and in good repair until the purchase price has been fully paid.

And it
And it is further provided that in case of default in any payment as above set forth for a period of one month or in case the purchaser should attempt to destroy the said building the whole of the purchase price shall immediately become due and payable, and the vendors shall have the right to take possession of the said building, wherever it may be situated, and may on giving the purchaser one month's notice in writing of the vendors intention so to do sell and remove the said building and apply the proceeds of the said sale in satisfaction of the original purchase price.

Provided however that if the amount realized from such sale shall amount to more than enough to pay the balance of the purchase price such excess shall be paid to the purchaser, and if the amount so realized shall be insufficient to pay the said balance the purchaser shall be charged with whatever sum may be required to complete the payment of the original purchase price.

And provided also however that if the purchaser within one month from the time of such notice shall pay the amount of the instalment which was in default together with any costs that have reasonably been incurred in taking possession of the said building, the purchaser shall again have possession of the said building until any payment shall again be in default.

In witness etc.

Sir,

I beg to submit the following report concerning the school on the Indian Reserve at New Germany.

1st. I visited the school on Thursday the 12th inst.

2nd. Number of pupils enrolled eleven.

3rd. Very small attendance for the last quarter.

4th. I found that only two pupils had attended from February 2nd until April the 2nd, and for the 3 weeks immediately preceding my visit there had been no school at all.

5th. The teacher reports that she has been present at the school-house to attend to her duties, but having no children to teach.

6th. The people on the Reserve complain that the teacher has not done her duty towards the scholars. She seemed to have lost all interest in the working of the school and thus, they claim, accounts...
for the small number of pupils who attended.

As this teacher was hired by my predecessor in Office I await orders as to what I shall do concerning the school for the coming year.

Singing "Where the Sugar Maple Grows" by school.

Assigning various portions of outdoor work to different pupils.

School dismissed at 12:45 and work in yard begun.

The smaller pupil picked up chips and put them into bags for future use; the larger pupils and teacher cleared the yard of rocks, repaired unsightly places, raked chips into piles etc., etc.

At 11:45 all claimed to be very hungry so we went to our various homes and got dinner. At 12:45 p.m. we again met at the school-house.

School called to order at 1 p.m. 7 pupils present.

Singing "The Trees" by the school. Roll Called.

Writing Exercise. School dismissed and work around resumed.

Plot for garden dug up. Fertilizer put into it and well worked in with the ground. Then we raked it off and shaped it, placing cut sods round the edges to keep it in shape.

We planted sweet peas, nasturtiums, scarlet runner beans, asters and sunflower seeds.

Planted on the north side of the School Yard.

Memorandum:

Mr. Featherston,

With reference to the attached memorandum of April 13th, dealing with the appointment of day school teachers, I have pleasure in informing you that as our school system is denominational, the appointment of day school teachers has never been considered a matter for political patronage. Very infrequently teachers have been recommended by Members of Parliament and have been appointed, but the instances in which the Department has applied to Members of Parliament for nominations have been extremely rare. Some schools require Roman Catholic teachers, some schools Methodist teachers, some schools Anglican teachers; that is to say the religious belief of the majority of the pupils governs the appointment of the teacher.

When the present Civil Service Act came into force I purposely did not hand over the appointment of the teachers to the Commission, and we continued to conduct our policy in the well established fashion, and I see no reason, in fact there is every objection, to altering it. If we were to hand it over to the Civil Service Commission, I would immediately suggest that the appointment of day school teachers be exempted from the operation of the Civil Service Act.

In view of the contradictory reports received with reference to the operation of this school, I think that it would be well to have a special report from our Agent or Superintendent and I propose to ask for it.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

In looking over the annual report of the Department of Indian Affairs, I notice an expenditure for the education of the Indian children on the Indian Reserve at New Germany, Lunenburg County, N.S. It is stated in said report that there are 4 boys and 6 girls attending school on said reserve under the heading of Indian affairs. This would naturally lead the reader to believe that the above mentioned children attending said school where Indians or Half-Breeds. This is not so; there is not one Indian child in said school. Neither is there one Half-Breed there all white children. Therefore the writer takes this as a matter of public interest and feels it his duty to inform you with the facts regarding the Indian Reserve in Lunenburg County. The facts are as follows: The Indian Reserve of one thousand acres is inhabited solely by white people who do not pay one cent of taxes. Have free school, free land, free use of the public highway, right of way, tax on all other property of the surrounding country. This in the writer's opinion is not British policy and should not be tolerated by a government whose hall of deliberation the British flag floats. However, stated if there is any doubt in your mind about the correctness of this statement you can have it verified by witness under oath, or you can consult William Huff, Esq., for Lunenburg County, trusting this will give you an idea how Indian affairs are handled over to white folks awaiting your early reply. I am Yours for British policy.

Jacob F. Penney

Communications have been received protesting against the Department continuing the day school on the New Germany Indian Reserve, Dunsman Co., S.S., and providing for the cost of its maintenance and payment of the teacher's salary. It is stated in these letters that there is not a bona fide Indian living on the Reserve, with the exception of one family (John Pietou) who moved there last winter from Minneapolis Co. On the other hand, petitions have been received signed by a number of the residents in which they request that they be left alone and the present arrangements continued.

It would appear that through intermarriage with whites over a long term of years practically all traces of Indian blood have been lost.

Jacob N. Penney, who is a Justice of the Peace, and has land on the Reserve, in a letter to the Honourable The Minister, states as follows:

"In looking over the annual report of the Department, I notice an expenditure for the education of Indian children on the Indian Reserve at New Germany. It is stated in said report there are 14 boys and 6 girls at school. This would naturally lead the reader to believe that these children are Indians or half-breeds. This is not so. There is not one Indian child in said school. Neither is there one half-breed. They are all white children. The Indian Reserve of 1300 acres is inhabited solely by white people, who do not pay one cent of taxes, have free land, free use of the public highway, free school."

He further states that if there is any doubt as to the correctness of his statement it can be verified by witness under oath.

George H. Zink, who resides on the Reserve, states as follows:

"As I live on the Reserve myself and am married to a Penney girl, born and bred on the Reserve, I should know something about the place. Let any gentleman visit the Reserve and see if they can find any Indians. I cannot understand why this place cannot be sold and the people put under taxation."

He further states that he would like to sell out, but as the position is now he cannot sell and give anybody a title to the land.
Our Agent, Dr. Chisholm, Mahone Bay, to whom this matter was referred, after being written on three occasions, finally reports that several of the families living on the Reserve are Indians. Judging from his letter, he has not enquired very carefully into the matter and has taken very little interest in ascertaining the facts as to the status of the residents on the Reserve.

The census of 1924 shows that there were 30 Indians on the Reserve, as follows:

- Under 6 years - 2
- 6 to 15 - 7
- 16 to 20 - 14
- 21 to 65 - 4

The nearest white school to the Reserve is stated to be 6 miles distant.

It would further appear from the facts that consideration should be given to the enfranchisement of the families living on this Reserve.

Dear Doctor Scott,

With further reference to your letter of the 14th ultimo, I beg to report as the result of my visit to the Indian reserve at New Germany, N.S., on the 7th instant, that its permanent residents are unquestionably white people, with the possible exception of Howard Beeler, who is the illegitimate son of Agnes Hammond before her marriage to Hosiah Beeler. Howard's mother is dead, but his aunt, Mrs. Dorey, states that her sister made a declaration under oath in the usual way, at or about the time of his birth, that his father was a white man named Dennis Jedrey. Mrs. Dorey's husband is also a white man. Howard himself states that he always heard his father was Dennis Jedrey. He does not follow the Indians much of life, and in fact there is nothing so far as I can see, to indicate that ever Indians inhabited this reserve. Now these are the facts, and it will be for the Department to decide whether I am right or not in my opinion that Howard (Jedrey) Beeler is a white man. He has always used the surname of his stepfather, who brought him up.

Mr. Agent Chisholm, of Mahone Bay, N.S., accompanied me on this visit to New Germany Reserve, where we met by appointment Mrs. E.B. Penny. It was very anxious that I should give Howard (Jedrey) Beeler the status of a white man; but I had to tell her that my duty was to submit the facts to you should decide the point. Both she and Mr. Chisholm are agreed that Beeler is the only permanent resident of the reserve, who may possibly be regarded as an Indian.

Howard (Jedrey) Beeler, whose

Dunlop C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
wife is a white woman, has six children of school age, who attended the Indian Day School at New Germany, when it was in operation. The other pupils were four purely white children, three of them the teacher's - and occasionally an Indian boy named John F. Pictou.

Now, Mrs. Penny complains that if she had been given timely notice of the Department's intention to close the school, she would have been able to secure another position as teacher, as she is qualified to take charge of any of the common schools in Nova Scotia, but that when she received notice it was too late for her to make application for such position.

Howard (Jodrey) Beeler also complains that if he had known the school was to be closed, he would have endeavoured to make arrangements by which his children might attend some other school. But I do not see how he could accomplish anything in that respect, in view of the fact that the nearest public school to his home is some four miles away.

Under these circumstances, I would suggest that the school be re-opened and kept in operation for the remainder of the present term, which ends on June 30th. next, giving all concerned due notice that it will be permanently closed after that date, unless it be decided in the meantime that Beeler is an Indian, and that his children should be educated by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Ottawa, January 3, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of December 27th with reference to the Toney children.

At the present time there are no vacancies in the Shubenacadie Residential School and, consequently, they cannot be sent there.

Would it not be possible to arrange to have them regularly attend a "white school" near their home. Please make enquiries in this regard. The Department will be prepared to allow the usual grant of $12.00 a year for each of the children, based on the average attendance.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

School opens today on Lunenburg Reserve, New Germany Day School.

Madam,

In reply to your letter of the 4th instant, I beg to say that you were engaged as teacher of the New Germany Indian School at a salary of $500.00 per annum, or $50.00 a month.

During the month of September, 1922, you only taught 12 days and you were paid the sum of $30.00 for your services for that period. Sir:

With further reference to the Department's responsibility for the residents of the New Germany Indian Reserve, I have now to inform you that Mr. Indian Superintendent Boyd's report has been received. Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th inst., No. 119697/5, which was before me yesterday on my return to headquarters from Bear River, N.S.

I have noted its contents and beg to say that, since the summer holidays began in July, I have been doing my best in the matter of repairs to Indian school buildings in Nova Scotia; but it has been impossible for me to undertake all the work of that kind that requires to be done. (Repairs and improvements have been completed in connection with the schools at Bear River, Whycocomagh, Middle River, Sydney, and Salmon River - the school house at Bear River having received the finishing touches this week.)

It was my intention to leave the other schools for next year, because repair work, especially when it includes painting and plastering, cannot be done to satisfaction in Nova Scotia during the fall and winter months. However, as I know that the statement of the teacher at New Germany regarding the condition of the school house there is quite correct, I shall endeavour to have it attended to, at least, in so far as unavoidable repairs are concerned.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have just received your letter of the 19th instant by Mr. Scott; and, to say, in reply, that some days ago I wrote the Indian Teacher at New Germany inquiring if some person could not be got near the place who would be able to make such temporary repairs to the school house as to make the roof watertight, and the building otherwise comfortable for the winter. I have not been favored yet with the desired information, but expect to be at any moment, when I shall know better what to do; but I hope it may not be necessary for me to travel nearly 300 miles to superintend such work as sweeping a chimney, or putting a stove pipe in order, or nailing a few shingles on a roof. I think the Agent Mr. Harlow, would attend to such matters, if the teacher brought them to his notice. But, at any rate, I expect to have the school house at New Germany put in condition for the winter at an early date. Of course, it requires somewhat extensive repairs; but there is no use in attempting to have them made until warm weather comes again. I did all the work in that line that I possibly could during vacation this year; but was not able to overtake what requires to be done at New Germany.

Please have the necessary action taken to purchase the desks required for the New Germany Indian School, Lunenburg county, N.S., from the Crowe Furniture Company, Bridgewater, N.S.

D.S.G.I.A.
Referring to your letter of June 21st, 1874.

I beg to say that the school in the school house at New Germany is in a very bad state. I was going to ask the authorities to have them overhauled, but as their has been a change and Mr. Freeman of Bridgewater will have the care of it, I hope he will see the need of the improvements and the department will consider them favorable. I think the change will be a benefit to both countries as it will do away with a good deal of travel.

You asked for estimates of the cost of having this work. I think that Mr. Freeman had better make estimate as he will have to see that it is done.

Your obedient servant,

Charles H. Atkin
Secretary Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Ottawa, June 29, 1912.

Sir,

It has been reported to the Department that the interior of the Indian school-house at New Germany requires some repairs. The plaster is loose and there is also some painting to be done.

I have to ask you to be good enough to obtain an estimate of the cost of having this work done so that it may be attended to during the summer holidays.

As soon as these repairs are made new school desks should be installed and when the proper time comes you may purchase:

6 single desks No. 5
6 rear seats No. 4

This purchase should be made from the Crowe Furniture Company of Bridgewater. I should be glad to have an acknowledgement of this letter.

A general letter of instructions with regard to schools will be sent you in due course.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir,

I have received your letter of Oct 31st 1916 regarding the school at [location]. I have made inquiries and calculated the cost per pupil for carrying the teacher to and from the school, which comes out to $0.50 per trip. I consider this amount reasonable and suggest that the department should make arrangements accordingly. However, I would suggest leaving the school closed during an occasional stormy day when roads are impassable, as this would practically be no pupils there on those days, thus saving costs.

The death of Mrs. [last name] has opened another question as to the disposition of the property on which she lived, since she left no children.

There is considerable dispute over the Indian Board's decision, and I would suggest the department take this matter into full consideration.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing a communication from Mrs. E. B. Penney, teacher of the New Germany Indian Day School, regarding her salary and bonus for the December quarter, last, the furnishing of wood for the teacher's residence and material for sewing.

Regarding the wood required for the use of the teacher's residence, I beg to say that the Department has allowed 5 cords each year. You may, therefore, arrange for the purchase of this quantity for the teacher's use. Competitive prices should, if possible, be obtained, and the purchase made from the person quoting the lowest price. When the wood has been delivered, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred, to which should be attached a memorandum showing the names of the persons asked to quote a price and the prices quoted by them. You should arrange for the purchase and delivery of this wood as soon as possible.

Regarding the wood required for the school building, I beg to say that we allow the janitor salary at the rate of $20.00 per annum, for which he is to keep the schoolroom clean, light the fires and furnish the fuel required. We, therefore, presume that the janitor is furnishing an ample supply of wood for the use of the school.

We note from the teacher's letter that she has purchased some wood for her residence. I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, reporting on your visit to the New Germany Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say it is noted that you found the teacher to be quite capable and properly attending to her duties, also that there are 6 or 7 children of school age who can attend. It is considered, in view of your report, that it is in the interests of these children to keep the school in operation during the next school year, and Mrs. Penny, the present teacher, may remain as teacher if she desires, for the school year ending June 30, 1924.

Regarding the repairs which you state are required to the building, you may arrange to have the repairs to the roof carried out, and the blackboards re-painted, and any broken panes of glass replaced in the windows. These repairs should be carried out during the coming summer holidays, and no unnecessary expense should be incurred. You should arrange for the purchase of any material required and for the labour in having the work done. Only the repairs absolutely necessary to the roof should be carried out. When completed, properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred.

I should be pleased to have the report of the officer of the S.P.C.C. after his visit to investigate conditions at Gold River.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, enclosing a communication from Mrs. E. B. Penney, Teacher of the New Germany Indian Day School, requesting that certain repairs be made to the building. As you were instructed by official letter of the 8th instant, you should arrange to have the repairs required to the roof carried out. Also have the plaster repaired where necessary and the walls cleaned.

The girls' toilet requires a new door. You may arrange to have the same put on.

The teacher further states that the well needs a box and that it should be fixed around the top with cement or bricks to prevent surface water from running in. Please have these repairs carried out.

As already authorized, you should have the blackboards repainted.

The Department does not wish to have any undue expenditure incurred at this school. While it is intended to carry on the school work for another year, the further continuing of the school will depend entirely upon the attendance during the next year. Until we are definitely assured that there will be a sufficient attendance to warrant the expenditure we are not prepared to authorize any large expenditure in fitting up the building. The above work should be carried out during the coming summer holidays. You will arrange for the purchase of any material needed and for the labour. Properly certified vouchers in duplicate should be forwarded covering all expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. S. Chisholm, Esq., M.D.

Can anything be done to provide accommodation for the teacher of this school? A residence appears desirable for the teacher at New Germany school, N. S., and the plans prepared for Shubenacadie will no doubt meet their requirements. It might, however, be accomplished, as the plans and specifications are already prepared, if the Deputy Minister approves of its erection.

Ottawa, October 31, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant with enclosures in which it is stated that, owing to the death of Mrs. Foster, with whom the teacher of the New Germany Indian School, Miss Rose L. Ford, was living, teacher's quarters are required, as there is no other suitable place on the reserve where she can live.

In reply I beg to say that the Department regrets that, owing to the lateness of the season and the want of funds, it will be unable to provide quarters for the teacher this year.

If the teacher can find accommodation in the neighbourhood the Department would be willing to pay for her transport to and from the school until the cold weather makes the roads passable. Kindly state the distance she would have to be conveyed and what would be a reasonable price to pay for it.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Secretary.

N. P. Freeman, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Bridgewater, N.S.
July 2nd 1917
Bearsdale No. 3

Mr. Freeman

I am sorry to bother you again about a place for our teacher's to live but must tell you what the trouble is & then you can think what is best to do.

Now the people on the Reserve seem to like the teacher we had this last term also think she wants to come back again but there is no place for a teacher to board as Mrs Hammond
I am enclosing letters received from Mrs. Ford and Mr. Beeler concerning the problem of rooms in a house for Mrs. Ford for next year. This matter was considered last year but nothing was done about it. Considering the fact that Mrs. Ford gives satisfaction and will likely remain for a few years if she has a room or two where she can have the children, this suggestion of Mr. Beeler seems worthy of your consideration, as there is no place else where she could board.

Anticipating an early reply,

I remain,
Your obedient servant,
E. M. Freeman
Acting Indian Agent

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant enclosing a communication received from Mrs. Ford and Mr. Beeler in reference to the need of living quarters for the teacher of the New Germany Indian School and suggesting that the Department purchase a house, which it is said can be bought for $50.00 and put in repair for $100.00 to make it suitable for the teacher.

In reply I beg to say that I am enclosing herewith a blank form of indenture, which you will be good enough to have filled in and signed by the recognised owner of the house. It will be necessary for you to fill in the description of the lot on which the house stands and this can be done by making a rough sketch showing the dimensions of the lot and the position of the house, which should be filled in in the blank space provided for the description or attached to the document. The measurements can be taken either from the house or from one of the adjoining lots and should be taken round the lot, so as to embrace the property.

When signed the document should be returned to the Department and upon receipt, if satisfactory, the money will be paid to the person entitled to it and you will receive full instructions in regard to the expenditure.

SURVEYS

Sir,

I am enclosing signed document as per instructions in letter 119697/5 of July 28th. The repairs necessary are as follows:

- Shingling the roof.
- Replace the window, three pairs of new sashes and glasses.
- Partitioning the building into two parts.
- Sheathing the walls and partitions.
- Furnishing a stove and the new doors.

There should be a brick floor as there is none at all in the building. It will cost about thirty dollars outside of the hundred to build that.

They expect to have the building ready for use the first of September if they receive a favorable reply.

Yours obediently,

E. H. Greenan
Acting Indian Agent.
